item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Output Board, Installation of a Grounding Switch and Repair of the Keypad
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is almost done. Today, I worked on Output PCB #8 and fixed a loose key on the keypad. The Output PCB #8 was initially in this condition: I prefer to replace the output relay as they tend to get stuck with age. Luckily, the relay is the same one used for platter RPM switching, so my custom replacement boards work here as well: These replacement parts are available to anyone interested; feel free to email me.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated DIN Plug
item.description: During the ongoing refurbishment of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, a corroded DIN5 plug was replaced after a new output relay had been installed. The original plug showed significant signs of wear. A high-quality Rean DIN5 plug with gold-plated terminals was chosen as a replacement. Photos document the preparation of the cable and the installation process. The author notes the limited space inside the DIN5 plug, making it difficult to separate the signal and ground connections.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjusting Platter, Sub-Chassis, Arm Lowering Limit and Tracking Force
item.description: To prepare the Beogram 4002 (5513) for testing, several mechanical adjustments were required. The platter needed to be perfectly aligned with the surrounding aluminum plates. This involved balancing the floating sub-chassis within its support brackets. After aligning the chassis and platter, the arm lowering limit was addressed. Finally, the tracking force was calibrated to match the tonearm’s weight dial. Prior to adjusting the sub-chassis, damaged cabinet guidance washers, crucial for securing the top aluminum plates, were replaced with 3D-printed replicas.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Another New Arrival - A First Impression
item.description: I received another Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable that needs some care. After unboxing it, I was pleased to see the effective packing method, similar to what I demonstrate in my 4002 shipping video. The sturdy metal construction of the 4002 makes it relatively easy to ship safely with proper double boxing and precautions. My initial assessment is positive. The aluminum surfaces are in great shape and will gleam with a thorough cleaning.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): More RPM Measurements
item.description: Following up on the Beogram 4002 (5513) from the previous day, I conducted an overnight RPM (revolutions per minute) performance test using my BeoloverRPM device. The resulting measurement curve demonstrates excellent performance, typical of DC motor models. It shows minimal fluctuations (less than 0.05%) over time, aligning with the service manual’s specifications. The initial upward slope, lasting a couple of hours, is a common trait in the 551x and 552x models.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of Bent System Ground Terminal
item.description: Following the installation of my newly designed BeoloverRIAA pre-amplifier into a recently restored Beogram 4002, I prepared to reassemble the casing. As I was about to secure the hood, I discovered the system ground terminal on the rear panel was severely bent and damaged. The damage to the threads from rust and deformation prevented the nut’s removal. I was forced to cut the bolt off. Once removed, I replaced it with a new 3mm bolt and used appropriate insulating shoulder washers.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with LEDs
item.description: During the ongoing restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the incandescent bulbs illuminating the RPM trimmer scales were replaced with LEDs for enhanced longevity. Custom-designed circuit boards housing SMD LEDs were crafted to seamlessly replace the original bulbs, ensuring a direct fit. These LED assemblies are offered to fellow enthusiasts, with an instructional video demonstrating their installation available online. The following images detail the RPM trimmer panel, initially showcasing the rear view with original bulbs in place.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Linear Tracking System
item.description: My restoration project of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable started with the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. These mechanisms often require attention because of hardened lubricants and misadjusted tracking sensors. After taking the mechanism apart for cleaning and lubrication, I addressed the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm, which commonly experiences stiffness due to hardened lubricants. The sensor arm was then removed for disassembly to further work on the linkage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A Broken Off Solenoid Plunger and New Transport Lock Bushings
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, recently serviced and returned to a customer, unexpectedly came back with a faulty tonearm. The culprit was a broken solenoid plunger, a part responsible for lowering the tonearm. This unusual breakage was likely due to material fatigue. To fix the issue, the solenoid was replaced with one from a donor Beogram 4002. During the repair, it was discovered that the transport lock bushings had also deteriorated and needed replacement.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors, RPM Relay and Trimmers on the Main PCB
item.description: Following the DC motor rebuild on this Beogram 4002 (5513), the main PCB was addressed. All electrolytic capacitors were swapped with high-quality, Japanese-made, 105C-rated capacitors. The existing Tantalum capacitors, known for their tendency to fail dramatically, were preemptively replaced with modern equivalents to avoid any potential issues. Images illustrate the original board and the sections targeted for capacitor replacement. The author designed a replacement for the original Siemens relay using a modern, fully encapsulated SMD relay.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor Bearings with Oil Infusion Under Vacuum
item.description: I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable and decided to address the DC motor while it’s open. Previously, I hadn’t realized the importance of properly lubricating the motor bearings for long-term stability. Simply applying grease provided a temporary fix, but RPM fluctuations would reappear after a few weeks. This time, I completely disassembled the motor to access the bearings. To ensure proper lubrication, I used a vacuum method with a mason jar and a FoodSaver pump.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the DC Motor
item.description: Following the reconstruction of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, I shifted my focus to the electronics, starting with the motor. While the turntable’s RPM stability was excellent, I believe a thorough restoration involves servicing every part, including the motor, to ensure long-term reliability and everyday usability.
